H0.text: Asteroids are the small, rocky bodies that orbit the sun.

H1.text: Comets are small, rocky bodies that orbit the sun.

H2.text: Meteorites are small, rocky bodies that orbit the sun.

H3.text: Fossils are the small, rocky bodies that orbit the sun.

A4.text: Asteroids are rocky, metallic, or icy bodies with no atmosphere, and are broadly classified into C-type (carbonaceous), M-type (metallic), or S-type (silicaceous). Asteroids are minor planets—an object larger than a meteoroid (thus 1 meter or larger) that is neither a planet nor an identified comet—that orbits within the inner Solar System or is co-orbital with Jupiter (Trojan asteroids).

A5.text: The main difference between an asteroid and a comet is that a comet shows a coma (tail) due to sublimation of its near-surface ices by solar radiation.
